title: It Hurts and Won't Make You Better
historical_context: This article reflects the nihilistic and countercultural sentiments prevalent in the hacker community during the late 1980s and early 1990s, a time when the internet was becoming more accessible but also more scrutinized.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, and those interested in counterculture and philosophical musings.
short_summary: The article presents a series of dialogues that explore existential themes and the futility of belief, wrapped in a narrative that captures the disillusionment of youth in a modern world. It combines humor with deep philosophical questions about existence and reality.
summary: In 'It Hurts and Won't Make You Better,' Obscure Images crafts a narrative that delves into the absurdity of existence through a series of dialogues between two characters, Jeff and Jared. Their conversations oscillate between mundane complaints about life and profound existential musings, questioning the very nature of reality and belief. The dialogue captures a sense of confusion and futility, reflecting a broader sentiment of disillusionment that resonates with the youth of the time. The characters grapple with the idea that perhaps nothing is certain, and that confusion might be the only reliable state of being. This philosophical exploration is interspersed with humor, making it both thought-provoking and entertaining. The piece serves as a snapshot of the cultural zeitgeist of the early '90s hacker scene, where questioning authority and societal norms was a common thread among the community.
